awd_titl_txt: Development of a Critical Zone Observatory National Office
awd_abstract_narration: This award will support the establishment of the Critical Zone Observatories National Office (CZO-NO). The CZO-NO will facilitate coordination of research and educational programs of the network of Critical Zone observatories (CZO) and provide a centralized entity, which will represent the network with the scientific community and the public. On behalf of the CZO program, the CZO-NO will coordinate activities like sharing of protocols, cross-science programs, training institutes, and integration with other major research initiatives. To facilitate communications with the scientific community and the public, the CZO-NO will update and maintain a program website and implement an outreach and education plan for the CZO program. The CZO-NO will work with the CZO community to share CZO discoveries, data and research opportunities with the broad community capable of using these data and information. The CZO-NO will provide a venue where scientists, students, and the public can communicate concerning the sustainable future of the Critical Zone.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Critical Zone Observatories CZO program established six sites for intensive interdisciplinary study of the Critical Zone, to better understand the interaction between geology, water, atmosphere, and ecosystems in both natural settings and settings with intensive land use.  The task of the CZO National Office was to provide create mechanisms and a platform to allow those observatories to work together and have broad collective impacts.  The CZO-National Office worked to promote contact among scientists, develop means of hosting and sharing data, provide a forum for discussions of techniques and protocols and identify common challenges.  The CZO National Office also developed scientific foci on cross-site science questions, those that could be best answered by comparing processes across multiple locations.  It also coordinated the development of outreach and educational materials about the individual CZOs and the overall concept of the Critical Zone for the general public and for use in both K-12 and higher education. An important accomplishment of the National Office was the development of a flexible and interactive electronic data system for data for the CZOs and more generally for future CZ science.  This was a substantial task accomplished with the close collaboration of the Consortium of Universities for the Advancement of Hydrologic Science (CUAHSI) through modifying their Hydroshare data system for the additional more complex data types generated by CZOs. The CZO National Office promoted collaboration with international partners in Europe, S. America, Canada and Australia, and hosted annual international meetings on Critical Zone science themes for scientists from the U.S. and around the world. It also led development of a young scientist network beginning with graduate students and post-doctoral scholars.  Many of the participants in that network went on to produce collaborative projects and a significant number of them moved into faculty or permanent staff positions at U.S. universities and other research institutions.  In this way the CZO program effectively advanced the science by dispersing young talented scientists trained in this new integrative way of approaching the Earth surface environment to top tier institutions around the country.

Overall, the CZO NO award partially or fully supported approximately 45 professional meeting presentations, 25 peer reviewed journal papers, 11 book chapters, 20 publications in specialized education outlets, development of 5 web sites, at least 60 education, outreach and other electronic products, hosted multiple workshops, blogs, webinars, produced two White Papers, and a Strategic Plan.  Educational materials developed by the CZO National Office have been part of a significant number of teacher professional training workshops about the Critical Zone. These workshops reached more than 700 K-12 teachers in 2020-21 alone.  Some of the responsibilities and resources of the CZO National Office were passed forward to the new Critical Zone Collaborative Network (CZNet), the next phase in the evolution of NSF’s Critical Zone research program.
